questions.question: The man .................................... I owed money demanded immediate payment.
questions.description: The man demanded immediate payment. I owed money to him. When we connect these two clauses, the relative pronoun whom replaces the pronoun him. The preposition 'to' is retained.

questions.question: The four brothers are always ready to go to .................................. help.
questions.description: Each other is used when referring to two people and one another is used when referring to more than two people.

questions.question: This is the woman ........................................... son was abducted.
questions.description: This is the woman. Her son was abducted. The relative pronoun 'whose' replaces possessive pronouns like her, his and their.

questions.question: The flight ...................................... at
questions.description: We use the present simple to talk about future events that are part of a time table.

questions.question: When I was young, I .................................. cricket every day.
questions.description: To talk about past habits, we can use would + infinitive. The past simple is also possible here.

questions.question: .................................... it possible, I would visit London
questions.description: Were it possible means the same as if it were possible.

questions.question: ....................................... it prove to be true, I shall resign from the committee.
questions.description: 'Should it prove to be true' means the same as 'If it proves to be true'.

questions.question: ......................................... many faults, he was a good man at heart.
questions.description: In spite of and despite mean the same. The expression 'despite having' is also possible here.

questions.question: Were you ...................................... to trust him?
questions.description: As an adverb enough goes after the adjective it modifies, so foolish enough is the correct option. Infinitive structures are not used after so.

questions.question: The faster you run, ............................................... yourself.
questions.description: The same structure 'the + comparative + subject + verb' is used in both clauses.

questions.question: If you played games regularly, you ...................................... get so fat.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: She ...................................... cooking when the guests arrived.
questions.description: The past perfect is used to talk about the earlier of two past actions.
